text: THE COMPTROLLER OENERAL
label: TITLE

text: O F  T H E  U N I T E D  EITATEB
label: H4

text: W A S H t N G T O N .  D . C .  2 0 5 4 8
label: BODY

text: DATE:
label: H4

text: A p r i l  13, 1983
label: BODY

text: DIGEST:
label: H4

text: Massachusetts National Guard technicians
label: BODY

text: who had elected State rather than Federal
label: BODY

text: retirement coverage, as provided in the
label: BODY

text: National Guard Technicians Act of 1 9 6 8 ,
label: BODY

text: improperly converted to Federal Civil
label: BODY

text: Service retirement after they separated
label: BODY

text: from the Massachusetts National Guard and
label: BODY

text: were later rehired. No reimbursement is
label: BODY

text: allowable for interest expense to restore
label: BODY

text: state retirement coverage, even though the
label: BODY

text: costs accrued because of mistaken and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized conversion to the Federal
label: BODY

text: Civil Service retirement system. The
label: BODY

text: Government is not liable for the unauthor-
label: BODY

text: ized acts of its agents. Further, without
label: BODY

text: a statutory or contractual provision for
label: BODY

text: interest and attorney fees claimed,
label: BODY

text: reimbursement of these items must be
label: BODY

text: denied.
label: BODY

text: Several Massachusetts National Guard technicians ,claim
label: BODY

text: reimbursement for costs of interest and attorney fees they
label: BODY

text: indicate they incurred because they were mistakenly placed
label: BODY

text: under the Federal Civil Service retirement system without
label: BODY

text: authority. The National Guard Bureau, Departments of the
label: BODY

text: Army and the Air Force, in submitting the technicians'
label: BODY

text: claims to us, recommends payment because of the mistake, but
label: BODY

text: states it could find no authority to allow the claims.
label: BODY

text: We find that the claims may not be paid because there
label: BODY

text: is no contractual or statutory provision permitting reixi-
label: BODY

text: bursement of the interest or attorney fees requested.
label: BODY

text: Without such authority losses arising fron mistaken and
label: BODY

text: unauthorized actions of agency officers and employees may
label: BODY

text: not be paid by the Government.
label: BODY

text: Backsround
label: BODY

text: The claimants were employed as civilian technicians
label: BODY

text: with the Massachusetts National Guard when the National
label: BODY

text: Guard Technicians Act of 1968, became effective in January
label: BODY

text: See Public Law 90-486,
label: BODY

text: 82 Stat. 755, August 13, 1968
label: BODY

text: S 709 and S 709 notes).
label: BODY

text: Under that Act, National
label: BODY

text: Guard technicians were changed from state employees to
label: BODY

text: Federal employees. Since many technicians were
label: BODY

text: participating in state retirement programs, section 6 of the
label: BODY

text: Act authorized them to elect before January 1 ,  1969, to
label: BODY

text: remain covered by their state retirement system rather than
label: BODY

text: switch to the Federal Civil Service retirement system. For
label: BODY

text: those who elected to remain with their state system,
label: BODY

text: section 6 of the Act also provided authority for the Federal
label: BODY

text: Government to make the required employer's contributions to
label: BODY

text: the state system.
label: BODY

text: The claimants in this case elected to remain covered by
label: BODY

text: the Massachusetts State retirement system rather than the
label: BODY

text: Federal system. At the time of election, they were informed
label: BODY

text: that their choice to retain Massachusetts State retirement
label: BODY

text: coverage was an irrevocable option for as long as they were
label: BODY

text: continually employed by the Massachusetts National Guard.
label: BODY

text: However, they were also told by National Guard officials
label: BODY

text: that they would be converted to the Federal Civil Service
label: BODY

text: retirement system if after separating from employment they
label: BODY

text: were rehired by the Massachusetts National Guard after the
label: BODY

text: effective date of the Technicians Act.
label: BODY

text: Later they did
label: BODY

text: separate, and after a break in service the Massachusetts
label: BODY

text: National Guard rehired them as technicians. They then
label: BODY

text: withdrew their contributions that had accumulated in the
label: BODY

text: Massachusetts State retirement system and were converted to
label: BODY

text: Federal Civil Service retirement coverage. For periods up
label: BODY

text: to 10 years, Federal retirement deductions were made from
label: BODY

text: the claimants' pay and, along with the Federal employer's
label: BODY

text: contributions, were transferred to the Civil Service
label: BODY

text: Retirement and Disability Fund.
label: BODY

text: However, in 1977 a question arose as to the propriety
label: BODY

text: of these acticns, and the Personnel Officer of the
label: BODY

text: Massachusetts National Guard sought clarification from the
label: BODY

text: United States Civil Service Commission (now Office of
label: BODY

text: Personnel Management), By letter of December 16, 1977, an
label: BODY

text: official of the Civil Service Commission informed the
label: BODY

text: Personnel Officer of the Massachusetts State National Guard
label: BODY

text: that under Public Law 90-486 an election in 1969 to remain
label: BODY

text: in a state retirement system was final, and a National Guard
label: BODY

text: technician could not convert to Federal Civil Service
label: BODY

text: retirement upon being rehired as a technician in the same
label: BODY

text: state after a break in service. This information revealed
label: BODY

text: that the claimants conversion to Federal Civil Service
label: BODY

text: retirement had been a mistake. Consequently the claimants
label: BODY

text: were transferred from the Federal Civil Service retirement
label: BODY

text: system to the Massachusetts State retirement system along
label: BODY

text: with the employees' and employer's contributions to the
label: BODY

text: Federal system.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the transfer of contributions which took
label: BODY

text: place, the claimants believe that they should be reimbursed
label: BODY

text: for other costs arising from their reentry into the
label: BODY

text: Massachusetts State retirement system after the intervening
label: BODY

text: period when they were mistakenly under Federal retirement
label: BODY

text: system.
label: BODY

text: The reimbursement requested includes two elements of
label: BODY

text: interest charged the claimants in order to fully restore
label: BODY

text: their Massachusetts State retirement coverage. At the
label: BODY

text: commencement of the interim period under Federal Civil
label: BODY

text: Service retirement, the claimants withdrew the balance of
label: BODY

text: their contributions then accumulated in the Massachusetts
label: BODY

text: State retirement system. All of the claimants request
label: BODY

text: reimbursement of interest that would have accrued on this
label: BODY

text: balance during the interim period had it not been withdrawn,
label: BODY

text: and which they indicate the Massachusetts system requires
label: BODY

text: them to pay. The second element is sought by six of the
label: BODY

text: claimants who believe they are entitled to reimbursement of
label: BODY

text: interest on additional contributions that they would have
label: BODY

text: paid into the Massachusetts State retirement system had they
label: BODY

text: not left that system during the interim period.
label: BODY

text: In addition, two of the claimants through their
label: BODY

text: attorney request the difference between their payroll deduc-
label: BODY

text: tions ( 7  percent of their pay) for Federal Civil Service
label: BODY

text: retirement during the interim period and what they say their
label: BODY

text: contributions to the Massachusetts State retirement system
label: BODY

text: ( 5  percent of their pay) would have been if they had con-
label: BODY

text: tinued that coverage uninterrupted. These two claimants
label: BODY

text: also ask that their attorney fees for presenting the claims
label: BODY

text: be paid.
label: BODY

text: Applicable Law and
label: BODY

text: Conclusions
label: BODY

text: Concerning the technicians' eligibility to be covered
label: BODY

text: by the Federal Civil Service retirement system, that was a
label: BODY

text: matter for determination by the Civil Service Commission
label: BODY

text: (now Office of Personnel Management) which has the authority
label: BODY

text: to administer that system. 5 U.S.C.
label: BODY

text: 8347; 55 Comp. Gen.
label: BODY

text: 684, 687-688 (1976); and Matter of Ortiz, B-193337, Janu-
label: BODY

text: As to the irrevocability of elections to
label: BODY

text: remain under state retirement coverage pursuant to the
label: BODY

text: National Guard Technicians Act, the Civil Service Commission
label: BODY

text: published the following information dated April 30, 1969:
label: BODY

text: R ( l )  * * * A technician's election to remain
label: HH1

text: in a State retirement plan is irrevocable and
label: BODY

text: cannot be changed later so that service
label: BODY

text: credit can be allowed under the Civil Service
label: BODY

text: Retirement System. "
label: BODY

text: Federal Personnel Manual Supplement 831-1, Subchapter S3,
label: BODY

text: paragraph S3-3, Installment 20, April 30, 1969. This pro-
label: BODY

text: vision was reissued December 10, 1971. Thus, as the Com-
label: BODY

text: mission officially advised the National Guard Personnel
label: BODY

text: Officer in the 1977 letter it was the Commission's position
label: BODY

text: that a technician's choice to remain under a state retire-
label: BODY

text: ment system was irrevocable and that conversion to Federal
label: BODY

text: Civil Service retirement was unauthorized, even after a
label: BODY

text: break in service and reemployment with the state.
label: BODY

text: It appears that the corrective action taken to return
label: BODY

text: the claimants to the state retirement system with concurrent
label: BODY

text: transfer of funds to that system was all the action the law
label: BODY

text: allows to correct the error. Although we have not been f u r -
label: BODY

text: nished a full accounting of the transfer of funds from the
label: BODY

text: Federal Civil Service Retirement Fund to the Massachusetts
label: BODY

text: system, we may assume that the difference between the 7 per-
label: BODY

text: cent Federal contribution and the 5 percent Massachusetts
label: BODY

text: contribution was used either to pay interest on the late
label: BODY

text: deposit to the Massachusetts fund or was refunded to the
label: BODY

text: employees. There is no authority we are aware of under
label: BODY

text: and attorney fees. However, the question of whether interesz
label: BODY

text: may be paid on the amounts erroneously paid into the Federal
label: BODY

text: Civil Service retirement system for the period they were
label: BODY

text: deposited in the Civil Service Retirement Fund is a matter
label: BODY

text: for determination by the Office of Personnel Management.
label: BODY

text: That office may be willing to consider further the question
label: BODY

text: of appropriate interest payments with respect to the amounts
label: BODY

text: erroneously paid into and held in the fund.
label: BODY

text: , which we could authorize payment of the claims for interest
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: or s t a t u t o r y  a u t h o r i z a t i o n  is r e q u i r e d .

text: t h e  p r e s e n t  case.
label: BODY

text: Also, w h i l e  t h e  c l a i m a n t s  may have i n c u r r e d  some
label: BODY

text: expense due to t h e  e r r o n e o u s  a c t i o n s  or a d v i c e  of t h e
label: BODY

text: N a t i o n a l  Guard o f f i c i a l s ,  t h a t  a l o n e  p r o v i d e s  no basis f o r
label: BODY

text: us t o  a u t h o r i z e  payment.
label: BODY

text: I n  t h e  absence of a s t a t u t e  pro-
label: BODY

text: vidincr o t h e r w i s e ,  t h e  United S t a t e s  is n o t  r e s p o n s i b l e  f o r
label: BODY

text: t h e  u i b u t h o r i z e d - a d v i c e  or acts of i t s  agents.
label: BODY

text: F e d e r a l  Crop
label: BODY

text: I n s u r a n c e  Cor?. v. Merrill, 332 U.S.
label: BODY

text: Accordingly, payment o f  t h e s e  claims is n o t  a u t h o r i z e d .
